paragraphs.text: Trump blames his predecessor’s environmentalism for the loss of jobs in Appalachia, but the reality is a long-running product of market forces, not liberal tree-hugging. That the president’s persistent nostalgia for a yesteryear America had such visceral effect on rural voters only betrays the entrenched anxiety of a region where decline is a multi-generational way of life.
paragraphs.name: 02e2

paragraphs.text: Coal mining— even with the best safeguards in place — is incredibly difficult, dangerous, unhealthy work. It needs to be replaced with other work, but those jobs need to be good jobs — not low-pay deadend service jobs — and when people start talking about “tourism” they are talking about low-pay, deadend, service jobs. So, we absolutely have to get serious — a Marshall Plan for the Appalachians — and do it right.
paragraphs.name: e7ce

paragraphs.text: I can only talk about what I remember. Back in the 70's, I had two friends who were coal miners. They came home every day black with coal dust from head to toe. But, outwardly at least, they were as happy as anyone I knew.
